title: Barbara Walters, 'View' hosts grieve former employee dead at 39: 'It’s a very, very sad story'
text:
CLOSE Actress and comedian Whoopi Goldberg surprised her fellow "The View" co-hosts with a visit to the set. Goldberg revealed she was deathly ill with pneumonia in March. USA TODAY

Barbara Walters is mourning her former assistant, who died this week of ovarian cancer at 39.

The former co-host, who also created the talk show and served as executive producer, remembered Lauren Brennan Anglero as "lovely" in a statement issued to USA TODAY Friday, by her rep, Cindi Berger.

“There was always a lot to juggle in preparation for a live show, but Lauren was a hard worker, always ready to spring when I needed something and did so with a beautiful smile," Walters' statement reads. "My heart breaks for her husband and beautiful twins.”

Whoopi Goldberg and her "View" co-hosts issued a "tough goodbye" Thursday for Brennan Anglero.

Joy Behar said the former employee "worked here for many years."

"She worked at ABC for 16 years, and her first job was at 'The View,' " Behar shared with viewers.

"She was only 39-years-old, and she leaves behind her husband, Jerry, and two lovely twins," Behar continued. "Our hearts go out to her family. It’s a very, very sad story – a 39-year-old girl. And it was a short illness, and she just passed away."

Goldberg made it a point to tell viewers to make their health a priority.

"So, make sure that you get yourself checked. If you’re walking around today, make sure you check yourself – make sure that you are doing fine," she said.

ABC's "Nightline" paid tribute to Brennan Anglero. She was described as someone who said "'yes' to every challenge thrown her way," and was "beloved by everyone, especially cherished by her colleagues at '20/20.'"

"Lauren adored her husband, Jerry, and their miracle twins, Aubrey and Mason, born four months premature, weighing just over a pound each," the tribute continued. "Lauren was their tireless advocate. Now two-and-a-half, they are thriving. They are her legacy, and their lives a gift Lauren left for the world."

In a letter to his employees, ABC News president James Goldston remembered Brennan Anglero as "kindhearted and joyful" and a "treasured member of 'The View' staff."

"She was a tireless colleague, well known for her ability to solve just about any problem, always cheerful and always ready to go the extra mile," Goldston wrote in the correspondence issued to USA TODAY Friday.

"Lauren will be greatly missed," he added.
